column10: What drew you to apply for this scholarship?
column11: What is a challenge or obstacle that you have faced, or are currently facing, and how might time on the trail help you to better meet this challenge?
column12: Where do you find inspiration when faced with challenges and obstacles? When has your courage surprised you?
column13: At the end of your hike (whether or not you complete the entire 2,190 miles), what do you wish for yourself?
column14: Is there anything else you would like to share or that we should consider as we are making our decision?
column15: If you are selected as a finalist, you will be contacted by one of the review team members for an interview. Please indicate how you would like to be contacted (phone, email, text).
column16: How did you hear about this scholarship?
column17: If you answered "other" above, please share how you learned about this scholarship opportunity.
column25: Tell us about yourself.

column10: I was drawn to this scholarship in particular scholarship because despite what I‚Äôve been through in life that many I‚Äôm still standing, still moving forward, and doing the best I can. After serving my community and supporting my family, I want to show up for myself and refill my cup. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm hiking the AT this year: it‚Äôs a gift to myself.
column11: 6 years ago, my dad was diagnosed with dementia. Initially, I was his primary caregiver for 6 months until I decided to move to Baltimore. In Baltimore, I built a beautiful life that I loved. One that was very different from how I grew up. I thought I‚Äôd never return home. Then my dad's condition worsened and my mom needed help, so after 3 years in Maryland, I returned to Pittsburgh. For the last three years, my mom and I have shared caregiver responsibilities and worked on our relationship by addressing past hurts. Moving back to Pittsburgh allowed me to be close to my dad, but was also an opportunity to face all of the things I ran away from. I had to make peace with my childhood marked by sexual abuse, family substance abuse, and moving literally every year. The past few years have a season of reckoning with my path and as I walk the AT, I want to cultivate my future. I want to show up for me like I show up for others in my life.
column12: When I‚Äôm faced with challenges, I look to my source and my inner guidance. I find solace and grounding in my life‚Äôs mantra: that things are always working out for me. I do whatever I can to soothe myself with positive words and a shifted perspective. Once I find the feeling of relief, I‚Äôm often rewarded with clear guidance for a path forward. My courage often shows up when I need it most. After moving back to Pittsburgh I quit a great job at a global tech giant to grow food and do community outreach at my community farm. It was the greatest career I‚Äôve made and bright me so much joy.
column13: I not much one for wishing but at the end of my hike, I hope to feel a sense of accomplishment for having showed up for myself day after day. I hope to see the value in making myself, my safety, my happiness, and wellbeing my number one priority. I hope to feel more at home in my body and to know that I can do hard things.
column14: I only just heard of this opportunity today, but it‚Äôs truly an incredible thing that you all have put together in Nate‚Äôs honor and I‚Äôm sure he would be proud. Thank you for your consideration and for encouraging and supporting people in their resolve to keep going.
column25: I‚Äôm 28 year old Black woman from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. I am a community organizer and an advocate for food and environmental justice as well as national parks. I‚Äôm an adventurer at heart and have always marched to the beat of my own drum. I love meeting people of all walks of life and I have a gift for learning languages and connecting with nearly anyone.

column10: I want to be on the trail more and hike the AT in longer sections but without the financial backing I am unable.
column11: I am the victim of long term sexual abuse in childhood and then a gang rape when I left home to try to begin a new life of healing. These traumas have left me with C-PTSD, anxiety and many other challenges. I actively am in therapy doing EMDR but did not see big changes until I actively began hiking in 2019 and then backpacking in 2023. I am now working on section hiking the entire AT and working to encourage others with similar mental struggles or experiences to join me. I also use this experience to help me stay connected to the homeless families/individuals that I help. Feeling the cold or heat while I'm out helps me to remember that they are sleeping in very similar elements but without all of the gear.
column12: I find inspiration in the trail and the connections I make while I'm on it. I feel complete peace and freedom when I'm on the trail. I have a confidence in my abilities and in trusting myself that I can carry into my "everyday life" with my kids and work. I found courage on the trail after doing GA in its entirety alone, for the first time. I had to work through mental struggles alone when I was tired and wanted to give up but found great comfort and celebration in others when I ended at a hostel and got to swap stories with thru hikers.
column13:
I want to find more peace and healing from my traumas. I don't get a lot of time for myself. I am busy helping so many people secure housing, stability, transportation and other means necessary to have a good life that often times I never get a moment for myself to reflect and find peace. 

I also want to find more peace and healing in my family. I am the third oldest of eight siblings; I did not always choose right for myself but I am now. I want the chance to show my entire family that healing is available. I also want to show women, of all ages, that solo backpacking and hiking is possible and that you are STRONG.
column14: I know that so many people need this. I really would love to get something like this to assist me but I am happy to read the stories of all of the previous recipients and how this has changed this life.
column25:
I am a dedicated single mom to three amazing children and work as an affordable housing manager, where I strive to make a meaningful impact in the fight to end homelessness. My passion for helping others find stability and hope is at the core of everything I do.

My work is very unique and very stressful. We are not a one stop shop in just collecting rent. My rental office houses the very first health clinic for my residents who are all afflicted with varying degrees of poverty. We seek to help the residents with food insecurity, transportation difficulties, childcare issues, etc.

Beyond my work, I am an avid backpacker and nature enthusiast. I firmly believe in the power of the outdoors to heal and inspire, especially for those navigating mental illness or distress. Hiking and connecting with the wild can bring profound renewal, and I‚Äôm passionate about sharing this perspective with others.

Balancing family, work, and my love for nature keeps me grounded, and I‚Äôm always seeking new ways to grow, connect, and make a difference.

column10: A friend of mine suggested it. I'm feeling stagnant right now. At this point in time in my life, I Had a goal to be aboard mercy ships as a surgical assistant. With the injury, my goals and dreams had to change... I'm just not sure what they are right now.
column11: I need to be mentally challenged, the Pennsylvania mountains will chew you up and spit you out that's for sure! It's been a mind game for me, getting back to where I want to be physically. I need new challenges, I need to be able to think on my feet in situations I haven't been in. I need to grow a little bit more. I want more than what I'm doing right now.
column12:
I look back and I see early in the injury where no one  believed in my recovery. I had to believe in myself. I looked to other athletes for guidance. Its so easy to beat yourself up mentally. 
So, I remember. I think about others' stories  I remind myself that the only thing that matters is in this moment and the choice that I make for myself.
column13: To be able to do it again! But mostly, to inspire another. That would be satisfying.
column14: Just thank you!
column25: Hello! I am a 46 year-old woman. I am an outdoor enthusiast! I grew up in the Arizona mountains, now transplanted in Pennsylvania. I enjoy backpacking and hiking along with being a surgical technologist up until my brain injury in 2018. Most of my healing from the injury took place in the woods on trail. It was the only place that my body would normalize! I now spend most of my time at my camper in Tioga hiking and backpacking. I host hikes for women, I teach women the hiking and backpacking ins and outs.

column10: I expressed my desire to thru hike the Trail to one of my nurses while in detox and she told me a friend of her‚Äôs had won this scholarship a couple of years ago. When I read about the scholarship, who it is in memory of, its mission, and how many people it is has helped I felt compelled to apply. I am trying my best to be able to come up with the money on my own but I am still looking for work and I plan to leave for Georgia in late March 2026.
column11:
I have suffered from suicidal ideation from a young age. I did not have a drug problem until my mid to late 20‚Äôs. Drugs made me want to die even more than I already did before I found them. I have had multiple serious suicide attempts, two of which I should not have survived, my Higher Power had different plans for me I suppose.

I struggle to get out of bed a lot of days. Being sober and unemployed while living at home in early recovery is hard. Depression is lingering and at times debilitating.

My main motivation every day is training for the AT. My BPD can only be treated through DBT and active participation on my part to consciously change the thought patterns and behaviors that allow me to relapse and succumb to active addiction, suicidal ideation, and depression.

The Trail is an opportunity to face mental health issues and overcome them.
column12:
When I face obstacles, I find inspiration in the people who remind me why it‚Äôs worth pressing on; my family, my friends, and those who have been there before me and found the strength to keep going.  I draw strength from stories of resilience and help push myself through with mantras like ‚Äúthis too shall pass‚Äù

Music is also huge for me, I was raised with love and music being the spiritual foundation of my household. I am encouraged by songs that I can relate to and find meaning in.
column13:
I hope that once I am standing on Mount Katahdin that I am able to stand a little more proud and have less doubts about my abilities. I hope that I have found some direction by then, maybe that I have gained some knowledge of my Higher Power‚Äôs will for me.

I don‚Äôt want to expect too much from my hike.

I want to enjoy the journey, the suffering and the joy, and be humble when I get there.
column14:
My family is amazing and they are all rooting for me.

My older brother died in 2009, I was 15 and he was 16, we were best friends.

My parents turned to drugs that summer to numb their pain and all of our plans changed and we are all still trying to get our lives back together these 16 years later.

My mom got a liver transplant 3 years ago in October, she is 3 and a half years sober. My dad and i shared a sobriety date for a time until I relapsed. My dad will be 3 years sober in November. My younger brother struggles with alcohol and mental health problems. Him and I have been hiking together.

My family looks to me for strength and that is pretty overwhelming at times. I believe getting to spend this time with self, away from everyone I know and love, for the first time in my life is the experience that I need at this point in my journey.

I am starting my NOBO thru hike on March 27th, 2026 and this scholarship would allow me peace of mind and financial stability to accomplish that goal.

My mom shared with me the other day that she believes the Cameron The Universe has been waiting for me to find is somewhere on the Trail because I have never remained so determined and focused to accomplish anything before in my life the way I am determined to accomplish my thru hike.
column17: A nurse at the detox facility I was admitted to in Keene, NH
column25:
My name is Cam LaFontaine. I am 31 years old and currently recovering from substance use disorder.

Last year I was diagnosed with Borderline Personality Disorder and that diagnosis has given me a better understanding of my behaviors and provided me a roadmap of sorts to guide me in my recovery.

I crave connection and seek perspective every day. Life has not been easy but the challenges I faced have shaped the way I see the world and the way I carry myself through it. I look for meaning in my sufferings and remind myself that each step forward brings me further from the place I am leaving behind and closer to a life of purpose.

The outdoors have been a place of peace, growth, connection, and introspection for me from a young age. 
I see the Trail as an opportunity to sharpen my self discipline and strengthen my mental fortitude. Ultimately these skills will help me to find long term sobriety and general stability in my life.

The Trail is an opportunity to endgame in something bigger than myself and spend time connecting with self as well as my Higher Power. The idea of getting to spend such an extended period of time alone while acing untold obstacles and having the opportunity to face them all with a clean mind and healthy body excites me to my core.

I‚Äôm motivated by my amazing family and very good friends; also the possibility of discovering the best version of myself. I have been wanting to hike the AT for about a year now since it came to me in a meditation. I have been conditioning for the better part of the summer by hiking and mountain biking. I have gotten a few 4k‚Äôs in.

column10: I came across a post on the AT subreddit which I‚Äôve been on for the better part of a decade. Nate‚Äôs story reminds me much of my own and what can happen to someone young and with a world of possibilities gets hurt and suddenly loses their way. I suffered for many years after my injury and separation with alcohol addiction and have been extremely lucky that I wasn‚Äôt further consumed by it.
column11: The biggest hurdle that I‚Äôve been facing for the last few years is the death of my best friend. In 2014 I was stationed at Ft. Carson Co and met Cole Wilson who was my soldier. For the years following we were inseparable and spent all day together. It wasn‚Äôt until 2019 that we had a falling out after with my depression in full swing and going through I divorce I had believed that prior infertility in my marriage may have included him as well. It didn‚Äôt, but ultimately it strained our relationship ship and I spent the next several years reaching out and waiting. It wasn‚Äôt until late 2023 that we finally reconnected, but by that time Cole had been diagnosed with brain cancer and had withdrawn. Cole lost his fight in 2024 and I haven‚Äôt been the same since. Most of my days I‚Äôm still reminded of him and am filled with regret, thinking back to spending Winters in Colorado hiking, snowboarding, or driving around in the snow. If I had the opportunity to push pause on my life without feeling like I was abandoning my responsibilities, I think spending time on a trail thinking about Cole would be life changing.
column12: I don‚Äôt believe in a higher power, although I wish I did at times. When things get tough I think about the people that I‚Äôve lost and how they lived and try my best to live for them too.  I wouldn‚Äôt say I‚Äôm the most courageous person, but when I face something uncertain I‚Äôve tried very hard to jump in with both feet. With school, with my job, with my now relationship with my wife. Despite all the things that occurred, I let myself be vulnerable and it wasn‚Äôt until late the best decision I made
column13: If I were to make it any distance on the trail, the only thing I would wish for myself was that I was able to make a positive impact on someone else during my time there and I was able to be present for that experience.
column14: This is the first time I‚Äôve ever heard of anything like what you‚Äôre doing for Nate, regardless of who you choose, im just glad there are other people out there trying their best to honor the people they care about and it makes me feel less alone for trying to do what I can in my own life.
column25: My name is Joshua and I‚Äôm 34 years old. I‚Äôm an army veteran and served 8 years in the army before being medically discharged and spending several years in school studying mechanical engineering.     After leaving the army I struggled to find my way, suffering from depression and withdrawing from most of the things that I loved most. After years of rocky personal relationships, divorce, and the death of my best friend I‚Äôve finally settled into life and have found stability, but find myself thrown into work and with a dulled sense of purpose. I am lucky now to have a loving wife, a job, and life that I‚Äôve built through years of struggle, but I still find that I‚Äôm not the same person that I used to be.

column10: I was told about this application through a friend. Since 2023 my dream has been to hike the AT. My only obstacle is the financial part. I am hoping that winning this scholarship will help to finally be able to hike the trail in its entirety.
column11: As I mentioned in the question above, I suffer from depression. I‚Äôve had depression off and on since COVID. Sometimes I feel like I am just stick in a whirlwind and can‚Äôt get out. Being outdoors is the only thing that truly makes me happy. I live in North Carolina so when I get to the point where depression is getting the best of me, I head for the trails. Being on the trails helps me to get out of my mind. It helps me to focus on positive thoughts. It helps me to forget all the troubles of this world. I am praying that being on the trail for 5-6 months will help with my depression. I am praying that being out on the trail will give me a new perspective on the way life should be lived. Being on the trial will allow me to be in a place and space that I love and am at my happiest.
column12:
When faced with challenges I find inspiration from my Lord Jesus Christ. I find inspiration from somewhere deep down in my soul that only God can give me. I pray and I meditate and I ask God to give me the strength and courage I need to overcome this challenge and so far HE has never failed me. 
At the age of 52 I have overcome so many challenges. I was a poor kid growing up in the ghetto. I was physically abused as a child and was told I would be nothing when I grew up. I got pregnant and had my first child at 19. So every day was a challenge for me. I overcame all of those challenges and worked to pay my way through nursing school. I became a nurse to help people and I love doing it everyday. Even when depression has me so down that I don‚Äôt want to be around other people, I go to work and smile because I know that God put me in this career to help others at their most vulnerable times. So my courage surprises me every single day that I go out not feeling my best but I still give my very best to any and everyone that needs me.
column13: I wish to find myself. By that I mean, I wish to find what it is that makes me happy. I wish to find peace and joy that you can get from being out in nature. I know the trail will provide.
column14: I would just like to say thank you for making this dream a reality to so many people.
column25: I am a 52 year old women who fell in love with hiking during Covid. I worked as a nurse in the ICU and went into depression after seeing so many deaths during COVID. A friend suggested I go out into nature and hike and I fell in love. Hiking helped me through depression.

column10: To fulfill a decades long dream of attempting and completing the AT.
column11:
I relate big time to Nate‚Äôs story.  My life has been affected by addiction since the beginning.  I come from two addict parents, and had to be the adult from a young age.  The cummulative stress from that lead me to my own decades long battle with alcoholism.  After many cycles of sobriety and relapse I am coming up on four years free from alcohol and am only now beginning to feel safe enough to think about what I want to be when I grow up.  I‚Äôm 41.  Fitness has been my savior through this process.  Pushing my physical body to its limits is something that has kept me grounded and willing and able to push on through the mental/emotional pain.  I grew up in East Tennessee, the Smoky Mountains are my home.  Post quarantine 2020, I decided to move to Maine because I have family here and have always been In love with the amazing nature it provides.  Two years ago I decided I wanted to drop everything and finally take the plunge to do my thru hike. My plan is to do a SOBO and ‚Äúwalk home‚Äù. Katahdin to Springer Mountain ( home being TN)  I pushed through the fear of logistics, the fear of ‚Äúhow do I just put life on hold?‚Äù ‚ÄúHow will I finance this?‚Äù  I‚Äôm not a woman of means, and the AT just always seemed like it was for more privileged people, another thing that was off limits to me. ( limiting beliefs I know)
Unfortunately for me, I had some medical/dental stuff come up that wiped out any of the money I had saved up to do the hike.  I felt very defeated, but kept training and hiking because I just ‚Äúknow‚Äù I‚Äôm supposed to be doing this.
So I‚Äôm 41 now, in great physical shape, I have some new super expensive teeth so that‚Äôs good.  And I would be so grateful to be given this chance at fulfilling a dream.
column12:
I find inspiration through past versions of myself.  I find inspiration from others in recovery.  I find inspiration from the deep, unending well
Of compassion and love that somehow rages inside of me despite so much darkness. 
My courage surprises me every day, to be honest.  It takes courage to even fill out this form.  Being human is scary- it takes a lot of courage to just show up in daily life.  For me, those every day victories are the things that keep me inspired.  I know it will require a lot of courage to attempt this hike, and for that, I have a LOT of courage.
column13: I think the thing that excites me most about this is not the physical- rather the mental.   My personal wish looks like increased mental fortitude.  I hope to achieve more self confidence and independence.  And space to really ponder what I want in life.
column14:
Not really, other than extending gratitude that this scholarship even exists.  I just found out about it, and also about Nate‚Äôs story.  
Maybe consider that I am child free and also pet free so I don‚Äôt have to worry about leaving any dependents behind?   (not that people who have kids or pets shouldn‚Äôt be considered for that reason. üò≠)
column25: Hello there!  I am Kelly.  I am a creative, active, kind, loving human.

column10: I‚Äôve been trying for the past few years to save for a thru-hike, but between rent and student loans have not been able to set enough money aside. This would be the perfect opportunity to get that funding.
column11: Besides being stuck in the full-time work grind to make ends meet, I‚Äôve been living as a transwomen in a time where it‚Äôs becoming increasingly divisive. Part of being in nature for me is becoming more accepting of myself since that‚Äôs who I will be spending the majority of my time with. It‚Äôs a chance to learn to be more okay with who I am and to realize I am capable of everything anyone else is. On top of this, most of the people I met on backpacking trips have been incredibly accepting and kind, just something you don‚Äôt get in the city everyday.
column12: The mountains are truly my biggest inspiration. Seeing these towering masses of land, knowing that everything this will rise and fall in its time (even if it‚Äôs over thousands of years), knowing that many have used their energy and strength to climb and conquer these mountains, knowing that there‚Äôs always more just over the ridge. It truly brings me back down to earth and grounds me in my body, but assures my this body is capable of anything.
column13: More confidence in myself. Between knowing I can be alone for that long and guide myself, as well as knowing I will come back with stories to tell. I think by the time I make it back to the city finally, I‚Äôll have more goals for myself and more realistic expectations. (Writing albums and finding a new career)
column14: My first few backpacking trips have been right around Fox Gap in Pennsylvania and every time I go I‚Äôve been dreaming of ending up there on a thru-hike!!
column25: My name is Penny! I‚Äôm a 26 year old punk musician living in Philadelphia who has been dreaming about getting out into nature more and exploring more of the country. I currently work as an Inventory Tech at a children‚Äôs hospital and play in 2 bands.

column10: There aren‚Äôt many days I go without thinking about the AT. I like to keep up with the community through Reddit and came across a post sharing Nate‚Äôs story and the idea behind the scholarship. It honestly brought tears to my eyes. Going through something incredibly difficult, especially as a young adult, alters you in a way most can‚Äôt understand. I resonated strongly with Nate‚Äôs story and the testimonials, which made me feel seen. I think it‚Äôs incredibly beautiful to honor their struggles and triumphs through this scholarship. I hope I can continue this legacy of creating a community of healing for all of us who feel alone in our struggle.
column11: Getting a surprise cancer diagnosis, specifically Acute Myeloid Leukemia, blew up my life in a way I didn‚Äôt even know was possible. In an instant everything I knew about my life, myself, my future, was gone. Confronting my own mortality at the age of 32 shattered my world. Truthfully I did not expect to survive, but three years later I am done with treatment, hopefully for good. In a way I‚Äôm grateful for the perspective I gained through this experience, but I am left wondering where do I go now? It feels incredibly important for me to not take this second chance for granted. For me, thru hiking the AT has become the single most important goal in my life. Not only because it‚Äôs been my longest dream, but because I do truly believe in the healing power of nature and community. Coming so close to losing my life gave me such a deep appreciation for the beauty all around us. Thru hiking the AT will complete a part of me that has been empty for a long time, as well as show me the path for the next chapter in my life.
column12: My friends and family would say I was very courageous to go through my cancer treatment, when really it felt more like just something I had to do to survive. I don‚Äôt know if I have a singular inspiration for overcoming challenges, but getting cancer and facing my mortality did teach me that it‚Äôs always worth it to try. Life is too beautiful and short to let it pass you by. I‚Äôm also inspired simply by the beauty of nature. I‚Äôm grateful for every sunset I get to see.
column13: My biggest wish is to have a better relationship with myself, so that I can have better relationships with others. I want to be proud of what I can accomplish. I want to meet people and hear their stories. I want to find some inner peace in order to begin the next phase of my life.
column14: Like many folks, thru hiking the AT has been a lifelong dream of mine. My family is from West Virginia and Maryland so experiencing the trail feels like a deep part of my history, one I would really love to experience. I also seek community in this difficult transitional period of my life, and what better place to do that than the AT, especially in honor of someone who knew how special it is. I thank you greatly for your consideration.
column25: Howdy y‚Äôall, I‚Äôm Elizabeth and firstly I want to say thank you for such an incredible opportunity. I'm 35 from Southwest Florida but spent my childhood summers visiting my mom in Appalachia, where I learned about the AT and later dreamt of thru hiking it one day. For nearly a decade I was in natural resources management, from being a park ranger to a wildland firefighter. It was my dream job and truly a privilege to get to call nature my office. Three years ago I had finally saved enough to attempt my dream of thru hiking the AT. That September before I was set to leave a routine blood test revealed I had leukemia. It‚Äôs been three years of treatment now; incidentally I just got my last dose of chemo yesterday! I don‚Äôt know where my life is going next but I‚Äôm hopeful for the future.

column10: I seen it and thought it was perfect! I had no idea this existed and I could really use the money LOL.
column11:
Ultimately. I live with my mom so I may as well be homeless. I have struggled with addiction. I am in college, but it's just easy to say "what the hell." So I feel as if I hike the trail, it will force me to stay sober. 

Sobriety is something I want and am seeking, it's just hard. It's super easy to give in and give up. I think being out there and being mindful of everything will keep me at it and ultimately help me achieve my goals.
column12:
God. Always. 
When I'm on my back and looking up, there's just something that keeps me alive. I woke up in a helicopter with a guy hitting me with cables and saying "lost ya," after a suicide attempt. 

So, I figure I am supposed to be here for some reason? 

There has to be something out there, otherwise, I wouldn't be here.
column13: I'll finish my bachelors degree, go to law school, and help those who cannot help themselves. I want to be a defense attorney. I think.
column14: I know I am "old" but I would appreciate this probably more than anyone LOL.
column25: I am a 38 year old male. Divorced for about 6 years and starting over. Lost my children. All because of a drug habit. I have ultimately sobered up and started college at the university of phoenix. I am going online. I hope to go to Law School afterwards. I have plans of hiking the Appalachian Trail because if something should happen to me (long story, bad luck seems to follow.) LOL. My sons can say well, my dad hiked the Appalachian Trail, instead of...my dad was a junky. I really don't want to tell anyone I'm doing it or going. I just want to go do it and then tell them. Telling people you're going to do something usually brings trouble or something...So I would rather go and do it and then say well I done it.

column10: Financial struggles
column11: Staying sober and working my life out
column12: Community
column13: To keep living life in a state of peace
column14: Please let me stay lol
column25: I‚Äôve thru hiked the AT in 2024 and did a 1300 mile lash through out 2025. The trail has made me a better person and I has kept me sober from hard drugs longer than I ever have been since I was 16

column10: The help. Helping Nates memory live on through us.
column11: My anxiety, I know I can do hard things and this is like the gold star, if I can do this I can do almost anything. And with my health I want to show others struggling they can do it.
column12: Music, the outdoors, being in the hot sun spot eases the soul. I think I find inspiration in my peers and other normal people who have done hard things. In my youth I dabbled in the drugs too much and am lucky to not be an addict, I thought that was courage at the time, saying yes to everything.
column13: I wish for happiness!
column14: I take a pretty good picture of salamanders. (And other wildlife) (but love the lizards)
column25: I have always loved the outdoors, the smell after it rains especially. I am working a job I adore, at a residential treatment center for children with autism. Technically I am a teachers assistant, but at 31 I am still a student myself. I love my pets, camping, and the beach. This can easily turn into a list of all the things I love as in life I try to stay positive. I struggle with my body image due to acne and a stomach issue(rumination syndrome) causing me to regurgitate randomly, I‚Äôve had it since I was young and it‚Äôs been a struggle to keep weight on sometimes. But I‚Äôm awesome. I love the color green.

column10: I am applying for the Appalachian Trail because it has been my dream to thru-hike it. Unfortunately, I cannot afford to do so right now. I have invested a lot of money into preparing for and taking the MCAT, and I also need to save for medical school applications, which cost thousands of dollars. Even though I currently have the time to hike the trail, I don‚Äôt have the financial means. Still, I know that one day I will complete the Appalachian Trail‚Äîit‚Äôs only a matter of when. Life isn‚Äôt guaranteed, and I don‚Äôt want to keep putting off something that means so much to me.
column11:
I struggle with food addiction. It‚Äôs something I‚Äôve faced for a long time and continue to struggle with. I know it‚Äôs likely something I will always be working through in some way.
As a kid, my family used to joke about how much I loved food. They weren‚Äôt wrong. I‚Äôve always derived a deep sense of satisfaction from food, definitely more than the average person. When I attended Valley Bible Church in Hercules, California during middle school, I volunteered in the kids‚Äô ministry mostly so I could enjoy the cinnamon rolls they served. I would sneak away from Kumon (learning center for children) in Pinole just to go to Krispy Kreme, try seasonal Oreo flavors at Walgreens, or sample new Lays ‚ÄúDo Us a Flavour‚Äù chips at 7/11. My love for food  was pretty innocent then and did not have much health consequences. I was active, played basketball, and although I was chubby, it didn‚Äôt stop me from having fun when I was young.
That changed when I was 17. A major family situation forced my mom to relocate us from California to Virginia. It was the most difficult experience of my life. My mom was working long hours. My older brother returned to California for college, and my younger sister had just started middle school. I was completely alone in a place I had never even visited before. In California, I had never been very popular. I was a fat, geeky Black girl who liked trying strange snacks, but I had grown up there and had friends there since I was very young. In Virginia, I had no one and I knew no one. That intense loneliness became the foundation of my food addiction.
I wasn‚Äôt in many classes, so I didn‚Äôt attend school regularly. I got a job at Walmart and used my paychecks to feed my addiction. Food became my comfort and my only real source of happiness. What had once been a quirky love of food turned into something much darker. In just three months, I gained 80pounds.
Eventually, my mom encouraged me to join the basketball team. This helped a little. I had more structure, movement, and fewer opportunities to binge out of boredom. But then the COVID-19 pandemic hit.
Between February 2020 and January 2021, I spiraled again. Without school or consistent work, I had too much time and too many emotional triggers. I gained 80 more pounds. Right before starting college, I tried to lose weight through extreme methods. I tried keto and even fasted for seven days at a time. It might sound contradictory for someone who binge eats, for some reason I could settle in extremes for very short periods of time. I had some success, but I was young and did not realize the importance of sustainability in pursuing health.This dietary pattern just resulted in worse binges. One memory I have is of ending my 7 day fast with Taco Bells and a donut ice cream sandwich from Donutz on a stick in Yorktown, Virginia.
Over time, I experimented with more strategies, like combining very low-calorie diets with long-distance walking. These attempts were still extreme and led to more cycles of bingeing and restriction. But one unexpected thing stood out. Walking made extreme dieting easier. Walking long distances eased my urges. It gave me something to focus on and made me feel in control again. During this period of experimentation with my body,  I found that having a distance goal was much more enjoyable than walking for a set amount of time. Mentally it was easier to tell myself to walk 10 miles to the grocery store in comparison to telling myself to walk for 1 hour. If I walked 10 miles to reach a destination filled me with adrenaline and excitement. Unfortunately, I did not connect the dots and use this discovery to make sustainable healthy changes in my life instead I used it just as a means to make torture easier. 
At the end of my sophomore year of college, my cousin passed away from a blood clot. This triggered intense health anxiety for me. I made the decision to leave college for a year and live with my mom in hopes of finally addressing my eating disorder and more importantly in my head then losing weight rapidly.A year prior to this, my mom lost her job and moved to Austin, Texas so my family was no longer in Virginia. Looking back, I realize that this was not the best decision. My parents were emotionally distant, and moving to a new city where I didn‚Äôt know anyone besides my mother and my sister put me back into a familiar cycle of isolation. Still, I‚Äôm no longer angry at my 19-year-old self for choosing what felt right at the time. I now look back on that year with gratitude. I struggled again with loneliness, but it was then I was able to connect the dots and realize my love for walking, not just as a tool for weight loss.
Before returning to school in the fall of 2023, I made one last extreme attempt to lose weight by walking 20 miles every day for a month. Unsurprisingly, it ended with overuse injuries after three weeks. But it was during that time, while searching Reddit for advice on long-distance walking, that I discovered the subreddit r/AppalachianTrail.
That discovery changed everything. Here I was walking 20 miles a day for absolutely no reason but a desire to lose weight. In contrast to the thru hikers that were getting ready to submit to Mount Katahdin, I became obsessed with trail life and the stories I found. While I was walking around my neighborhood with random distance goals, thru-hikers were moving with clear direction, heading toward a summit. I started to dream about doing a thru-hike myself. I would tear up watching people as they submitted Mount Katadhin, the thought of hiking the Appalachian Trail carried me through the rest of my unrealistic walking plan. It was then that I realized. For me, walking made me very happy. It didn‚Äôt just make dieting more tolerable because there was less time to eat. I, Munachi, enjoyed walking. I started incorporating walking into my life in a healthier way. I stopped using it as punishment. It gave me peace in my body, and for the first time, I stopped trying to harm myself to fit society‚Äôs beauty standards. I no longer pursue extreme diets. Now, I try to eat clean and move freely. Since August of 2023, I have lost 140 pounds going from 350 to 210. I am still fat, but I am healthy and I can move freely. My blood pressure is no longer high, I no longer have prediabetes.  
Struggling with addiction, whether to substances or food, is not a straight path. It‚Äôs complicated, emotional, and often isolating. That‚Äôs what makes this question so difficult to answer. I‚Äôve faced binge eating, but I‚Äôm also still facing it. With some addictions, like alcohol or drugs, you can abstain completely. With food, you can‚Äôt stop eating. What I‚Äôve learned is that walking gives me a kind of compassion that‚Äôs similar to the feeling food once gave me. It gives me purpose and dopamine in a healthier way. The thought of walking for months on the Appalachian Trail excites me deeply. The Appalachian Trail isn‚Äôt just a longer version of the walks I do every day. It is an American pilgrimage. It‚Äôs a space where others are walking their own difficult paths. Walking was once something I used to punish my body to make it smaller, it is now something that I do to experience simple joys in life and to see the beauty of the World. Everyday on trail, I would be doing something I already love with a true goal at the end.. Thank you for reading. I am sorry that it is really long.
column12: I find inspiration in people who have faced the same challenges I am currently dealing with. In any challenge, my first step is to speak to someone that has overcome said challenge. This has helped me personally a ton. When someone asks me for advice, I try to respond from my own life experience and the lessons I have learned along the way. I do the same when talking to myself. When I feel the urge to self-isolate, when I get anxious about my appearance, or when I believe I should not do something because of my weight, I remind myself that giving in to those feelings has never worked out for me in the past.That mindset is what helps me stay courageous and take action, even when I feel unsure or uncomfortable. It has led me to try things I knew I might not succeed at, simply for the experience and the joy of doing them. Last spring, I competed in a climbing competition at my school. Climbing is a sport where being lean offers a big advantage, and I knew I did not have that. I also knew I probably would not win. But I still showed up and competed. I surprised myself by not only participating but actually having fun. For me, courage is not about winning or being the best. It is about not letting fear or shame decide what I can or cannot do.
column13: I wish for myself the adventure of a lifetime.
column14: No, but thank you for this opportunity.
column25:
My name is Munachi, and I am 23 years old. I am from Hercules, California, a small city in the San Francisco Bay Area, but I have lived across the country in the last few years. I graduated from William and Mary in August 2025 with a degree in Biology, and my family now lives in Austin, Texas.
I am an adrenaline junkie who loves outdoor adventure, especially rock climbing, backpacking, and whitewater rafting. I first went rafting on a college field trip last spring, and ever since, one of my biggest dreams has been to become a whitewater raft guide.
Right now, I am working as a medical assistant while studying for the MCAT, which I will be taking in January. Outside of work and studying, I love to read. My favorite book of all time is The Autobiography of Malcolm X, and I am currently reading Crime and Punishment by Dostoevsky. I am the middle child of three siblings. I have a dog named Moses who I liked to go hiking and biking with.

column10:
Initially I saw this scholarship posted on Reddit in an Appalachian Trail group. I opened your website with no intentions of actually applying. I‚Äôve never applied for a scholarship before because I never felt like I was worthy of winning it, and nothing in other scholarships ever resonated with me.
 
The love with which you speak into the life Nate lived is so beautiful. Just getting to read his story, and about the incredible life he lived is fantastic. The way you describe him is what drew me to actually apply. I hope that if I am chosen for the scholarship, I‚Äôll be able to take a little piece of Nate‚Äôs story along the trail with me and spread his light just a little farther and a little longer; and if I‚Äôm not, I know that those you choose will take that light with them (maybe I‚Äôll even meet them along the trail and Nate will hang out in the conversations we have).
column11:
I feel like my whole life has been a bit of a challenge. I am very lucky that I am not someone who suffers from a substance abuse disorder, but I did grow up in households with family members who suffered. I experienced a lot of trauma in the first two decades of my life and I‚Äôve been trying to figure out how to heal from it since then.
I‚Äôm so blessed to have a loving and supportive spouse, sister, and so many friends and church members which have helped me, but I still have something underlying that needs to heal.

I felt the calling from the trail 6 years ago, and it hasn‚Äôt let me go. Next year is when I finally have the time to get out there, and I‚Äôve dedicated that time to being intentional about facing the things that I‚Äôve buried without the distraction of the rest of the world. I‚Äôm seeking trauma therapy now in preparation for the spring so that I‚Äôm fully prepared to meet myself in the peace and solitude of the trail.
column12:
I mostly find inspiration in God when I‚Äôm facing challenges. Knowing that I am on this planet for a purpose helps to get me through when it feels impossible. Knowing that I was not guaranteed a life without suffering, and that the suffering is helping to prepare me for something doesn‚Äôt make it easier, but it helps me to know that I will make it through. 

I don‚Äôt know that my courage has ever surprised me. I think I‚Äôve always been a courageous person. I have had to do hard things my whole life, and I know that if I am convicted to do something it means that I will get whatever I‚Äôm meant to get out of it even if I fail. Maybe the most courageous thing I have done is apply for this scholarship, because I am needing to be rather vulnerable about admitting that I am struggling with my mental health right now. I suppose it also surprised me a little bit when I sought help from a therapist and actually admitted how I was feeling underneath the put together person I want to be.
column13:
The first thing I will likely wish for myself at the end of the hike is a long, hot shower and a big juicy steak. 

After that, I really wish that the hike was not made in vain. 
I wish for my future self to have some semblance of peace in my soul, more compassion for myself, and maybe the courage to slow my regular life at home down a little bit so that I can keep that peace. I also wish to be someone who can help future hikers better than I can now because I‚Äôll have some experience to help relate to them better.
column14: I can‚Äôt think of anything else to share. I know you have a really tough decision to make, and I wish you all the peace in choosing the people you feel Nate‚Äôs legacy will help the most. I appreciate that you are considering me, and even if I‚Äôm not chosen I thank you for sharing Nate‚Äôs story with me.
column25:
This question is always so difficult to answer. Like everyone else, I am so many things, and those things are constantly changing.
First and foremost, I am a Christian. This is the central identity that governs everything else about me. It‚Äôs what gives me strength through difficult times; more importantly, it‚Äôs what causes me to try to show love and light to every person I‚Äôm privileged to meet. 
I‚Äôm also a wife, an aunt, a sister, a granddaughter, a dietitian, a community member, a survivor, a YouTube personality, and now I‚Äôm a hiker. 
I hope that when I‚Äôm asked this question in one year, I can say that I‚Äôm a scholarship winner, and a thru hiker!

column10: Would love the opportunity to spend one more day hiking as I think each day we are able to get outside let‚Äôs us reconnect with what‚Äôs important in life.
column11: In 2024 I was planing on moving to New Zealand for a work opportunity. I was engaged, split up with my ex, and moved back in with my parents to help my mom battle cancer instead, lost my job due to taking time off for her and then really struggled to find my own worth. My whole life was work work work and now what became really important was my family and what you can‚Äôt get back. Time.
column12: I think about my family, how they would react and what they would say to me. If I can talk to them I imagine how they‚Äôd push on and continue to charge hard. The type of mentally they instilled in me as a child. A figure it out and problem solve mentality.
column13: A realization that money isn‚Äôt everything and the people you meet along the trail are the true gift.
column14: Hiked the PCT in 2025 and found it to be a life changing experience. The people and trail community allowed me to have a new lease on life
column25: Grew up working all my life, parents were adamant about working hard and showing dedication to something. When I turned 25 I moved to NH for work and fell in love with hiking and the mountains

column10: I will retire end of this year and have saved a lot towards my thru hike. I will not be able to draw Social Security and will dip into retirement funds. I will also be on the open market for health insurance for one year until I turn 65 for medicare. The scholarship will help overall and take some of the cost from our household funds.
column11: I am a living kidney donor and donated my left kidney to a stranger 4 years ago. After some time we met and have become good friends. I wanted to show people that donating and becoming a living donor does not stop you from an active life. There are over 100,000 people in the US alone waiting on a kidney to save them and they spend hours on Kidney Dialysis Machines two to three times a week. They cannot go on vacation their life is tied to dialysis. If my story encourage just one person to donate then it would be a success.
column12: I find inspiration in quilting and hiking. I belong to a ground called Quilts of Valor and we donate quilts to Veterans in my local area. When I feel down or missing my family back home I like to get outside and hike with my dogs.
column13: That I can inspire others at my age and with one kidney to enjoy the woods, go hiking, biking that life is too short and you are not promised tomorrow.
column14: I also only have one lung, due to childhood illness my right lung is partially collapsed. This also adds when hiking uphill but slow and steady.
column25: I am originally from Dublin, Ireland, left home at the age of 24 and have lived away longer than I have lived in Ireland. I return every 3-4 years to see my family. I am 63 now and hope to challenge myself on the AT in 2026. I am married, one son and 3 grandchildren. I am an avid hiker and trail runner.

column10: I saw the help u were giveing other people with struggles and really hope I would be able to find the help I need because the stories I saw you changed peoples lives.
column11: I grew up in foster care after being abused and left on the street by my mom at age 7 I stayed in foster care where I was often abused and mistreated and passed from place to place till I was 18 where I was left on the streets again. I was forever into sex work to survive. I have been homeless and live in my car I have no family or any help last year nov 18 i woke up with the right side of my body paralyzed went to dr man was forced to have emergency a CDF surgery to replace my disk that was completely compressing my spinal cord. I had the surgery February 3 of this year. I still have drop foot and partial paralysis in my right hand, but I will not let this stop me
column12: my courage surprised me when I woke up and I thought I had a stroke, but I didn‚Äôt and the fact that I still get up every day and function after everything I‚Äôve been through in my life without turning to drugs or alcohol amazes me every day
column13: to know that I inspired people who have been through similar things or who will go through them in the future. to also allow nature to heal me physically spiritually, and mentally I may still have dropfoot or partial paralysis at the end, but the rest of my body will be healthier and better because I didn‚Äôt allow that to stop me
column14: I really truly want to inspire people who have been through hell and high water and show them that no matter what you can accomplish amazing things I honestly want to do the triple crown, but it starts with the AT
column25:
My name is Vanessa Fuller, and I‚Äôm working to make my dream of thru-hiking the Appalachian Trail a reality. This hike isn‚Äôt just about miles‚Äîit‚Äôs about reclaiming my life after years of struggle and showing how nature can heal.
My mother was an addict who abused me and left me when I was 7. I spent the next 11 years in foster care, moving from place to place and facing abuse along the way, until I turned 18 and was left completely on my own.
In November 2024, I woke up out of the blue with drop foot and partial paralysis in my right hand. I had ACDF surgery in February 2025, which helped my neck but didn‚Äôt fix my hand or foot. Living with these challenges makes everyday life harder, but I refuse to let them stop me. This hike is my chance to show that resilience, courage, and determination can overcome even the hardest obstacles.
I plan to share my journey on social media to show how the trail can heal physically, mentally, and spiritually. Support from your program would allow me to take this journey safely and inspire others with every step.
Thank you for considering me.
Vanessa Fuller

column10: I‚Äôm really struggling the last few months with depression. I love being outdoors and the AT has been kind of my splice.
column11: I‚Äôve been dealing with medical issues, severe asthma, diabetes, depression and survivors guilt. Time on the trail would allow me to focus on myself and how to deal better with these issues as well as helping me both with my physical health and my mental health.
column12: Outside actually.. when I am facing a challenge I usually try and find river or a creek to walk near. Seeing how a slow moving river slowly eroded a mountain.. Just reminds me to keep going and that no obstacle is too big if you keep working at it.
column13: Peace in my heart and a sense of accomplishment. I know without this scholarship my dream of hiking the AT won‚Äôt happen.
column14: Not really, I just want to say than you for making this available for people like me who may never have the opportunity to do something like this. The benefits mentally and physically are immense.
column25: 47 fathers of two, Married for 22 years. 3 grandkids. I deal with depression and survivors guilt.

column10: I need financial assistance to pull off an ambitious goal to set a record for most miles hiked by a woman in a year. I am raising funds for both the cPTSD Foundation as well as the National Immigrant Justice Center on this challenge and I am not near my goal for funding to make the hike happen in  bc general right now. Support on this journey would mean everything to me and give hope to many other immigrants, women, and LGBTQIA+ facing the reality of the country right now.
column11: I am still struggling with my mental health, depression and anxiety which further reminds me that this is a disease and not a choice because I truly am so grateful to be alive. I would like to attempt something that feels impossible to remind myself of the strength I possess even when I feel weak. Hiking the AT would be a dream as well as to finish my triple crown.
column12: As a woman who has gone through a rough childhood which landed me in places like women‚Äôs shelters growing up, being raised by a single mother, diagnosed with endometriosis and  chronic pain, I have turned a lifetime of adversity into a thirst for action. I have a deep mental pain cave and doing hard things in what gives me the confidence that I can handle anything, pain is temporary, and to dig deeper than ever.
column13: I wish that I could remember my body is not broken, it is strong despite my endo, it is strong despite me feeling weak at times, and that when I dream I really reach for the stars because I know anything is possible. I wish myself peace.
column14: I am attempting to hike the calendar year triple crown this year, funding for the AT would be a huge relief. I‚Äôve been working full time over 45 hours a week and living off of $50 a week for food and groceries. For me, any little bit would help immensely. I am a mental health advocate and I hike for mental health.
column25: My name is Lauren or Lolo ‚ÄúSparkle‚Äù Veloz and I am a queer Mexican living in Denver, CO. I came to America at 6 years old and am part of the first generation to live here, now I‚Äôm trying to choose my path but the outdoors has become my passion.

column10: I only have about $3000 to thru-hike the AT NOBO, the PCT SOBO and then thru-float the Mississippi. Ive applied for many sponsorships to help but nothing so far. Regardless on a sponsorship or not I will go until I cant. Everything is on the line and I won't stop until I tackle this crazy dream in hopes it will help fix me. The trail provides so really im not too worried. Whatever happens will happen. Thats life.
column11: Call it a midlife crisis. Im currently unhappy with my current way of life, my job, where I live and just everything about my life. I feel like I am stalled out and just merely existing. Im currently in the process of selling everything, cars, appliances everything i own besides backpacking gear. The trail on the PCT in 2018 gave me clarity for 6-7 years for what i wanted at that point in time but now im lost yet again and needing the trail to guide me somewhere new. Im undertaking a much larger goal this year on the AT, the PCT and the Mississippi river as I figure more time alone will give me a better plan for the future. I hiked the PCT in 6 months but in reality days spent hiking was 3 months. I found that hiking fast, long 14-18 hour days is actually what I enjoyed the most. I plan on packing out paper and envelopes on trail for hikers to send letters to either family or friends or even complete strangers to build community through a dying art of communication. Communication is the most important thing in my life and being 100% real. Social media has taken a lot of life out of me and really only looking for the trail for healing and direction as well as building bonds with people that will ultimately become family.
column12: The only time I feel inspired, like ever has been when I am on a long distance trails, completely distant from what's going on in the world, politics, religion, sports, everything. The only thing that inspires me are the people that do what I do and enjoy spending months at a time sleeping on the ground, being hikers trash and living in the moment.
column13: Im going to complete the hike without a shadow of a doubt because the AT is just the first adventure for 2026. What I wish for myself is purpose, a desire to live, a desire to break away from the social norms, that desire to inspire people like the person I am now that thru-hiking changes lives! Its rewarding yet difficult and upon either completing the whole trail or just finding you're along the way, that your mental health always needs improvement and thru-hiking is in my opinion the only medication that has ever worked for myself. Without hiking, without the trails across the US and the world theres nothing else for people like me to fall in love with. It gives me purpose to live another day to fight for others going through the same thing and hopefully shed a light to others looking to find peace through the battles of physically pushing yourself to empower your mental strength
column14: Regardless if I am picked or not I want yall to pick whoever will best serve your purpose. I feel like this is personal for me and I know others are going through much worse than I am.  I am looking for assistance to make this journey a little easier, but also having that struggle of being financially inadequate may make my hike a little harder but rewarding as well. Im losing a lot going into this hike, giving up a house and 80 acres of property that I have caretaker for a non profit, given away my animals and ive lost all the joy I once had for all my hobbies but my mental health comes first Regardless if I lose everything else.
column25:
Do you ever feel like you are not seen for who you are? My life summed up in that question. 

I am 7 foot tall and that is all people look at. There is nothing more that people want to know other than how tall I am. Of course it has never always been this way as I was never always this tall but in adulthood its the sole focus on everyone I meet. There is no connection past.

Previously up to 2018 I was definitely introverted and scared of social interactions. I worked jobs that allowed me to work independently and remotely. I kept to myself because I feared human interaction, community, and found more enjoyable memories on my own. However this also plays a huge role in depression, overthinking, anxiety and a whole slew of other problems and it begins to eat you alive.

I suffered from chronic depression leading up to 2018 on my thru hike of the PCT and nearly took my life several times. That was the idea initially for hiking the PCT as it was a way to distract my family into thinking I finally found a purpose in life and that I found what made me happy. I had a long drawn out plan for the PCT that would make it look like an accident happened and that was how I imagined it. 

The trail saved my life on day 1. The people I met on day 1 brought a feeling I had never felt before. Safe, included, loved, seen. Each day after that my depression slowly dissipated and I fell in love with the community, the outdoors, the trail life, and life in general. I was a long haul trucker before the trail and could barely walk, much less hike. The first day on trail was brutal, 11 miles for the day, ran out of water by midday, and eventually met up with my tramily who were all in the same boat. We were all miserable, unprepared and disorganized and I finally felt like I wasn't alone.

Fast forward to now, it has been 6 years since my last thru-hike on the Colorado trail and this happiness is wearing thin. I stumbled back into my old rhythm and know the only thing that ever worked before was a thru-hike. 

Im currently in the process of selling everything I have, paying off all my debt in hopes to hike the AT the PCT and do a thru-float on the Mississippi River in 2026. With current calculations I will have a mere $3000 for it all but even without assistance my mind is set on getting my life back in check. I have never found anything else that works for happiness that actually works besides hiking.

I am also not interested in social media as I know that has been a huge role in getting me into this funk. There is no personal relationships, everyone is divided on ever subject and I plan on permanently deleting all but one social media page that I will be using for blogging for the trek. I feel like what I want is actual communication, growth, and to free myself from the social norms that really isn't normal. I want to have 1 on 1 conversations in person whether gsce to face or a phone call. Its personal and  shows the emotions that texts do not. On dayb1 onnthebAT I plan on deleting social media with a post highlighting what I want and to leave my phone number for anyone that truly wants to be in my life, otherwise the trail is my life and the people that inhabit the trail.

I plan on Journaling everyday writing everything down and once a journal is full I am sending to a pen pal I have never met but she has accepted that she will hold onto them until my journey is complete. I plan on writing a book upon completion of my goals and what I learned along the way as well as show insights to others that might feel the same way. Im socially expired by social media and looking forward to the trail providing the life in remembered and loved from the PCT. One step in front of the other and one positive moment after another. The trail provides and I have to be willing to let it work its magic on me.
column35: my soul feels the need to hike the entire AT or as far as I can go. The expense of proper equipment is a downfall for me. But it‚Äôs something that I must do.
column36: With a diagnosis of I‚Äôm going completely blind around the corner. I‚Äôm scared. I need this hike. I need to see everything I can while I can. I need to take pictures so my daughters can tell me-about them when I can‚Äôt see them with my own eyes. Taking this  thru hike will give me and maybe someone else they encouragement to never stop living.
column37: When I‚Äôm face with challenges, I find my inspiration in my children‚Äôs eyes and their words. Or I will often find myself in the backyard near thebiggest tree crying my eyes out and somehow it makes me feel better more grounded. My courage has surprised me when I had to deal withmy baby brother Committing suicide in front of me when he came home from Iraq.
column38: to always see, even when I cannot.
column39: it is such a blessing to just be considered for this opportunity so thank you for all you do.
column50: I am a 50-year-old female. Mother of two girls. I have been given a diagnosis of going blind. I have two rapidly mutating genes that is causing my sight to go. I am finding that being outside and taking in every thing I can while I can helps ease my some of my fears. I have been made to stop working and draw disability now.

column10: I have always wanted to thru hike the Appalachian Trail. Over the years I have put off the trail because of physical or emotional disabilities that I have battled over the years.
column11: I have been dealing with PTSD for many years. After surviving horrible domestic abuse as well as the death of one of my children, my mental state was affected by PTSD. This affects me in my every day life. Being on the trail helps myself and my children to connect and be present. It helps my mental health to be out in nature.
column12: My kids are what keep me going. I want them to know that we can do anything if we put our minds to it. My courage has most surprised me in 2011 when I made the decision to take my kids (the 15 year old was under a year old) and move to the Caribbean. After renting a cabin, and buying flights I had $300 for the next month. I had to figure out how to make things work fast! I just KNEW that I needed make this work for myself and my kids
column13: My goal at the end of the trail is for myself and my kids become closer and have better mental health.
column14: Hiking is important to myself and my family. We live on a very small budget and we hike with what we can afford. We are a family that is always together
column17: I heard about the scholarship from a hiking group on facebook that I am in.
column25: I am a 52 year old mom of 6. I have 4 adult kids and 2 young kids who are 15 and 11. My 15 year old has profound autism and cognitive disabilities. He will always need assistance for the basics. We love to hike together as a family.
